review.title: On bicluster aggregation and its benefits for enumerative solutions
review.abstract: Biclustering involves the simultaneous clustering of objects and their attributes, thus defining local two-way clustering models. Recently, efficient algorithms were conceived to enumerate all biclusters in real-valued datasets. In this case, the solution composes a complete set of maximal and non-redundant biclusters. However, the ability to enumerate biclusters revealed a challenging scenario: in noisy datasets, each true bicluster may become highly fragmented and with a high degree of overlapping. It prevents a direct analysis of the obtained results. To revert the fragmentation, we propose here two approaches for properly aggregating the whole set of enumerated biclusters: one based on single linkage and the other directly exploring the rate of overlapping. Both proposals were compared with each other and with the actual state-of-the-art in several experiments, and they not only significantly reduced the number of biclusters but also consistently increased the quality of the solution.
histories: 15 pages, will be published by Springer Verlag in the LNAI Series in the book Advances in Data Mining
review.COMMENTS: 15 pages, will be published by Springer Verlag in the LNAI Series in the book Advances in Data Mining

metadata.title: On bicluster aggregation and its benefits for enumerative solutions

sections.text: Tags: Bicluster, Bicluster enumeration, Bicluster aggregation, outlier removal, key figures for Bicluster.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 2 Definitions and Related Work
sections.text: Let us now consider the data set A-Rn · m, with rows X = (Br, Bc), where Br X and Bc Y are defined in such a way that the elements in the bicluster have a coherence pattern. A bicluster solution is a series of biclusters represented by B-Bi = (Bi) qi = 1 and contain q-Bicluster. A bicluster is maximum if and only if we cannot include any other object / attribute without violating the coherence threshold. If a solution does not contain maximum biclusters, the result is redundant, because there are biclusters that are part of larger Ones. Madeira & Oliveira [10] categorizes the types of biclusters according to their similarity patterns. They categorize the biclusters structure as biclusters.

sections.heading: 2.1 MicroCluster Aggregation
sections.text: MicroCluster [9] is an enumerative proposal which, after the enumeration, comprises two further steps: these steps have the task of deleting or merging bicluster that are not substantially different from other biclusters. The first step is the deletion step. If we find a bicluster in such a way that the ratio of its surface covered by no other bicluster is less than one threshold in relation to its total surface, it can be removed. The second step is the merging step. Let us look at two biclusters and create a third by merging rows and columns of the previous two. If the ratio of the surface of the third bicluster that is not covered by any of the previous two is less than one threshold in relation to its total surface, we can combine the two biclusters into this third. In this method of aggregation, maximum biclusters are not removed in the deletion step, which does not interfere with the final result.

sections.heading: 2.2 Aggregation Using Triclustering
sections.text: Since they have been able to improve the biological relevance of the Bicluster for microarray data [14], we will use this method as a contender in this paper. An important point in the overall result is that we want to combine the results that enhance the Bicluster, which seem to be important for several components, and discard those that can arise from noise. Due to the way the Bicluster algorithm handles the optimization step, non-maximum Biclusters can interfere with the end result. Bicluster aggregation differs slightly from Bicluster ensembles. While in ensemble tasks we discard Bicluster, which seem unimportant, and combine those that contribute most to the solution, in Bicluster aggregation we never discard a Bicluster solution.

sections.heading: 2.3 Other Aggregation Methods
sections.text: Gao & Akoglu [12] used the minimum description length principle to propose CoClusLSH, an algorithm that returns a hierarchical set of biclusters, which can be considered an aggregation step based on the LSH technique as a hash function; candidates that are hacked on the same bucket are then aggregated until no merger improves the final solution; their work focuses on finding biclusters in a chessboard structure that does not allow for overlapping and is therefore not suitable for the kind of problem we are dealing with. Liu et al. [8] proposed OPC tree, a deterministic algorithm for preserving clusters (OP clusters), a general case of Order Preserving Sub Matrices (OPSM), are not suitable for the kind of problems we are dealing with.

sections.heading: 3 New Proposals for Aggregation
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Aggregation with Single Linkage
sections.text: With this solution, we transform each bicluster into a binary vector representation as follows: In view of the dimensions of dataset A, Rn · m, each bicluster becomes a binary vector x of length n + m. For a bicluster B, which is transformed into the binary vector x, the first n positions represent the rows of dataset A, and if the bicluster contains the ith row, xi = 1, otherwise xi = 0. The last m positions represent the columns of dataset A, and if the bicluster contains the ith column, xn + i = 1, otherwise xn + i = 0. After this transformation, we use the hamming distance to apply the individual line arrangement to the existing biclusters.

sections.heading: 3.2 Aggregation by Overlapping
sections.text: It seems intuitive to aggregate the biclusters with an overlap rate above a defined threshold. This proposal is based on aggregation by pairs: While we have two biclusters with an overlap rate above a given threshold, we remove them from the group of biclusters and include the result of the functional aggregates defined in Equation 2, taking these two biclusters as arguments. Letters B, C, D and E are biclusters. Note that for D = aggregates (B, C), ov (D, E) ≥ ov (B, E) and ov (D, E) ≥ ov (C, E). Therefore, the order of aggregation does not fit into the final result.

sections.heading: 3.3 Outlier Removal
sections.text: After aggregating the results, we have to process each last bicluster to search for objects and / or attributes that can be interpreted as outliers. In this work, this step is always performed after aggregating with one of our two suggestions. Let B = (Br, Bc) be an aggregated bicluster, with | Br | = o, | Bc | = p. We define a participation matrix P, where each element pij indicates the number of biclusters that this element participates in. For example, if one element is part of 15 biclusters that B is composed of, then its value will be on the P matrix 15. Thus, we explain the process of outlier removal using Figure 1. We have two steps of outlier removal: one for the objects, the other for the attributes. To possibly remove outlier objects, we take the mean and the standard deviation of all columns on the partition matrix 1, which means that we view the whole page < 1.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: In our experiments we used three artificial datasets: art1, art2 and art3; and two real datasets: GDS2587 and FOOD. We designed the artificial datasets to represent different scenarios with increasing difficulty. They have 1000 objects and 15 attributes. Each entry is a random integer drawn from a discrete even distribution on the set {1, 2,..., 100}. Then we added: 5 bicluster arbitrarily positioned and without overlapping on the article 1; 5 bicluster arbitrarily positioned and with a similar degree of overlapping on the article 2; and 15 bicluster arbitrarily positioned and with varying degree of overlapping on article 3. For each bicluster the quantity of objects was randomly drawn from the set {50,., 60}, and the quantity of attributes stored on the server.

sections.heading: 6 Considering Remarks and Future Work
sections.text: The artificial data sets were characterized by a controlled structure of biclusters and were useful to show that aggregation can greatly reduce the quantity of biclusters while increasing the quality of the final solution. Our proposals exceeded the algorithms compared to the first two artificial data sets and showed that they were more resistant to noise in the third artificial data set. We also checked whether aggregation could obtain enriched biclusters in the case of a gene expression dataset. For different values of the RIn Close algorithm, we could see that the different methods of aggregation produced very similar results. Finally, the main challenge of aggregation with a single link is to decide where to cut the dendrogram, but as we could see, this task was simply to distribute across the tested datasets. Except for triclustering, all aggregations returned only bicluster. Finally, we compared the recommended methods to the biclusters.

metadata.abstractText: Biclustering involves the simultaneous clustering of objects and their attributes, thus defining local two-way clustering models. Recently, efficient algorithms were conceived to enumerate all biclusters in real-valued datasets. In this case, the solution composes a complete set of maximal and non-redundant biclusters. However, the ability to enumerate biclusters revealed a challenging scenario: in noisy datasets, each true bicluster may become highly fragmented and with a high degree of overlapping. It prevents a direct analysis of the obtained results. Aiming at reverting the fragmentation, we propose here two approaches for properly aggregating the whole set of enumerated biclusters: one based on single linkage and the other directly exploring the rate of overlapping. Both proposals were compared with each other and with the actual stateof-the-art in several experiments, and they not only significantly reduced the number of biclusters but also consistently increased the quality of the solution.
